Manuscript materials, sound recordings, photographs, and moving images documenting the performance of North Indian Bengali music; Jamaican music; African American gospel quartets and choral music; Irish folk dance and music; bluegrass music; African American hand dancing; and Andean music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through September 1993.
Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress),
D.C. Commission on the Arts and Humanities,

did.abstract: Manuscript materials, sound recordings, photographs, and moving images documenting the performance of North Indian Bengali music; Jamaican music; African American gospel quartets and choral music; Irish folk dance and music; bluegrass music; African American hand dancing; and Andean music recorded live outdoors on Neptune Plaza in front of the Thomas Jefferson Building, Library of Congress, at concerts from April through September 1993.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: The 1993 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection consists of manuscript and print materials, sound recordings, graphic materials, and moving images that document the 1993 concert series sponsored by the American Folklife Center. The annual series, which began in 1977, features the presentation of folk traditions from many cultures. The concerts take place on the Neptune Plaza at the front of the Jefferson Building of the Library of Congress between April and September. Adverse weather conditions sometimes force the concerts indoors.

The 1993 season consisted of the following:
Date Performers Place of Origin Subject
April 15 Master Performers and Their Apprentices District of Columbia Northern Indian, Begali, Jamaican, and Gospel music
May 20 Traditional Irish Music and Dance - Tom and Maureen Doherty New York and Pennsylvania Traditional Irish music and dance
June 17 Northern Lights Massachusetts Bluegrass music
July 15 Philadelphia Ambassadors Chorale and Ensemble Pennsylvania African-American sacred music
August 19 African-American Hand Dancers District of Columbia African-American hand dancing
September 16 Ollantay Virginia Pan-Andean music

bioghist.head: Administrative History
bioghist.p: Documentation created and accessioned by the American Folklife Center in 1993.

note.p: The following terms have been used to index the description of this collection in the Library's online catalog. They are grouped by name of person or organization, by subject and listed alphabetically therein.

controlaccess.head: Organizations
controlaccess.corpname: Archive of Folk Culture (Library of Congress), collector.
D.C. Commission on the Arts and Humanities, sponsor.
Philadelphia Ambassadors Chorale and Ensemble, performer.

accessrestrict.head: Access
accessrestrict.p: Listening and viewing access to the collection is unrestricted. Duplication of the materials requires prior permission of the Center and may be governed by copyright and other restrictions. Performers may be contacted through the American Folklife Center administrative office.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 1993 Neptune Plaza Concert Series Collection (AFC 1993/002), Archive of Folk Culture, American Folklife Center, Library of Congress, Washington, D.C.

row.entry: Tom Doherty, Maureen Doherty-Macken, Mick Moloney, and Regan Wick present traditional Irish music and dance. Wick, a champion step dancer, performs set dances, reels, a hornpipe, jig, and an a capella dance. Print materials and photographs: folders 6-9; sound recording: AFC 1993/002:SR2; videotape: AFC 1993/002:V2.

Demonstration of hand-dancing, a local couple dance derived from the lindy hop that has seen a recent revival in the Washington African-American community. Folklorist LeeEllen Friedland narrates and provides background information. Three couples demonstrate basic steps and individual variations, as well as other dances in the repertoire such as line dances, the Bop, Walk, Slop, Birdland, Bugaloo, Jerk, Twist, and line dances. Audience participation included. Print material, photographs, and slides: folders 20-26, envelopes 3-10; sound recordings: AFC 1993/002:SR9-11; videotape: AFC 1993/ 002:V5.
